And Sweet Tooth is the star of the series once again. I hope that a few critics with soapy eyes, who watch shows and judge them by the "judging cliche checkmark book 101" won\'t rob us from second season or even a new installment in the series! Definetley must watch'), ('9', "Absolutely loved it. Quirky and all, but best show I've seen in a long time. Hope they renew."), ('5', 'I want there to be another season… but I want it to take itself more seriously. There’s a lot of potential if they drop the comedy facade and focus on calypso and the effed monkey paw wishes - the whole reason for twisted metal to exist at all.')}
critic_reviews: {(4.0, 'Twisted Metal is noisy and violent, with some decent performances, but that’s about it.'), (3.0, 'Its general mode of operating is to put in whatever seems cool and fun and silly and sick and leave out anything that does not meet those parameters. Yes to: guns, cars, sardonic needle drops, wisecracks, blood, sex, flash, grime, the sound of tires on pavement, shit that looks dope. No to: quietness, finicky world-building, thinking too hard about the limitations of the human body, complex motivations, depth, taking stuff too seriously, man.'), (7.5, 'If “The Last of Us” excels at creeping terror and existential dread, “Twisted Metal” realizes that sometimes the appeal of the post-apocalypse genre lies in the simple pleasure of living vicariously through a likable hero dispensing one-liners while racing across the American wasteland.'), (5.0, 'Twisted Metal – a Peacock series spun out of the PlayStation game – manages to start with a rush of zany energy courtesy of the writers behind “Deadpool,” before hitting potholes as it becomes too over-the-top to justify the ride.'), (5.8, 'Fans of the games will be thrilled by Sweet Tooth’s scene-stealing brio, if not the structure of the show’s premise; we have another Mortal Kombat (2021) situation on our hands, an adaptation that serves primarily as a set-up for more to come. But if low-budget and low-brow bloodletting is your thing, there are far worse roads to travel.'), (4.2, 'There might have even been a better version of this show that wasn’t scared to really center Stu as the lead, a normal guy in a sea of abnormal weirdos. In that version, the writers wouldn’t have been so tied to a protagonist like John who thinks he’s charming but is really just bland. And it could have allowed other supporting players from the series to pop in and out. Instead, we’re stuck in a car with John and Quiet, wondering when this road trip is going to end.'), (3.0, 'An aggressively unfunny adaptation of a one-dimensional decades-old PlayStation franchise that few still care about, Peacock’s R-rated action-comedy breaks down from the start and never recovers.'), (8.0, "Twisted Metal is absurd and hilarious in exactly the ways you want a dystopian Cannonball Run to be. Yes, it matches the games' crude humor but, mostly, it springboards from there and creates its own dark and warped wasteland sensibilities."), (4.2, "Like so many modern streaming shows, Twisted Metal feels like it would work way better as a movie than a miniseries. Tricky as this tonal balance is, it's a lot easier to maintain for two hours than 10."), (6.8, 'Although its late-stage tie-ins to its source material and cliffhanger ending didn’t do much for me, and I have a general allergy towards its brand of blood-splattered gags, the characterization of these endearing misfits left me eager to see what stretch of road they’d visit next.'), (7.5, 'The show’s plot, especially, is total nonsense, sending Mackie racing across a decent chunk of the country with a ticking clock that never seems to meaningfully tick. There are ideas, images, and jokes worth seeing here, to be sure. But it’s a long trek to get to them.'), (7.5, 'Mackie, borrowing some comedic delivery stylings from Eddie Murphy, proves again he’s a welcome lead actor, effortlessly playing the humor while also evincing the anguish of John’s past that’s brought to the fore through flashbacks. .... Sometimes characters from these episodic adventures recur as “Twisted Metal” engages in satisfying world-building.'), (7.0, 'Quite decent. Both as colorful and as deep as a shimmering oil slick on a sweltering stretch of abandoned blacktop, Twisted Metal lacks the budget and ingenuity to consistently live up to the game’s sense of unrelenting mayhem. But its limitations make room for a solid character-based story to develop around stars Anthony Mackie and Stephanie Beatriz.'), (7.0, 'It crashes and burns as an action-comedy, but out of those ashes is an edgy rom-com, and believe it or not, it works. Even the episodic obstacles they face around the backend improve as comedic performers Chloe Fineman and Jason Mantzoukas pop in. They provide unhinged performances that leave you wanting more.'), (7.5, 'This is a screen-popping, wickedly funny, seriously twisted and action-jammed adventure that leaves us wanting more. Think “Mad Max” meets “A Clockwork Orange,” with a little bit of the aforementioned “The Last of Us” as well as “The Walking Dead” sprinkled in like so many scoops of lemon pepper.'), (6.5, 'Action is well-choreographed, the kills are gnarly, and watching various cars fly around and flip over in dramatic fashion never stops thrilling. In these moments, the show delivers on the high-octane thrills a name like "Twisted Metal" promises — and the finale offers all the chaotic, explosive violence that feels like a video game come to life. It\'s a shame, then, that the show all-too-regularly bogs itself down in overly familiar plotlines, instead of letting the craziness take over.'), (6.7, 'The shift to comedy also mostly works, thanks to a great writing staff that includes Rhett Reese and Paul Wernick of Zombieland and Deadpool fame, and a team of characters that embrace the weird world they’ve been thrown into. Twisted Metal might be a scrappy little mess at times, but it mostly works when it hits the gas.'), (2.5, 'John and Quiet squabble in painfully contrived fashion, resulting in reheated monologues about trust and vengeance that would play poorly in any context but are particularly galling here, padding the runtime of an otherwise interminably wacky series.'), (3.0, '“Twisted Metal” is not flawed because it’s a game adaptation. Its flaws still speak to why “The Last of Us” was an exception to an otherwise ironclad rule, and how copying that show’s playbook is not a surefire formula for success. The story of “Twisted Metal” is thin and packed with tropes.'), (3.0, 'It’s shallow enough to feel disingenuous, and the flatness of the characters doesn’t help. A horrific, ’80s-set origin story for Sweet Tooth becomes just another excuse for gratuitous gore.')}

title: Scott Pilgrim Takes Off
user_reviews: {('6', 'i really like this show, but i dont appreciate how vulgar the "scenes" are. I watched this with my little sister, and I had to put my hands over her face because of how crazy scott pilgrim got. shame on you netflix'), ('4', 'It\'s honestly just kind of boring the voice actors are generally just waaaaaay past their time and it shows they often sound bored or uninterested plus the entire plotline doesn\'t make sense sometimes I get it\'s supposed to be different from the movie but it just doesn\'t really make sense to me I don\'t really know how to feel about this show it\'s different but not a good type of different it\'s also just not really that bad it\'s more of a "I guess I\'ll just watch this since I have nothing better to do." type show.'), ('4', 'Im afraidnthey are trying to change the concepto from the cómics its cool but not what i exprcted'), ('8', 'tl;dr: ----Pretty fun although some characters feel flat. I\'d recommend to watch the movie before the show.--------- General Opinion: The show is fun, beautifully animated, heartwarming, and the music and sound design are on point. There are scenes that live rent-free in my memory like the first of \'Whatever\' or the fighting scene of \'Ramona rents a video\'. And some jokes make me chuckle when I randomly think about them, like: "I am Scott" and "Emotional business, find me a witness". ------------Characters: At first I was kind of disappointed because the show leaves on the bench characters that I love from the books. But we already got the story of those. So, after realizing what the show was doing, I was glad to see the anime focusing on others. Todd and Envy are a weird case. As they were well developed in the books, now they serve as support characters for Wallace. I wish they had something more going on. -----------Conclusion: I am divided in my opinion on the show. On the one hand, I feel like it misses the opportunity to gather a new audience as its metanarrative is highly dependent on the movie. On the other, I was hyped, surprised, and highly entertained. The changes on the anime were worth but I still prefer the books. I wonder if I would feel different if the marketing had been honest. ------------ One foot note I need to express: Bryan Lee O\'Malley shows his personal struggles in Scott Pilgrim, leaving gaps for you to fill with your own. Hence, as a teenager, the books showed me how to grow up from my painful experiences. And as an adult, the show gave me the courage to finally talk to my girlfriend about a problem we have been sitting on for almost a year.'), ('2', 'Why it\'s called "Scott Pilgrim" if the show is not about him? Anyhow, it\'s usual Wokeflix show.... If you want to watch something better than this then I suggest you to re-watch the movie with Michael Cera. It wasn\'t great but it was waaaaaaay better than this.'), ('9', 'Just as The Big Lebowski defined a generation, Edgar Wright’s 2010 "Scott Pilgrim vs. The World" became a cult classic adaptation of Bryan Lee O\'Malley\'s comic of similar name. (And a great game too!) Thirteen years and one divorcé later, both the comics and film have, my most measures, been critiqued more than any other piece of media this past decade. Culture critics alike have lampooned the series, notoriously Negative XP\'s song \'Scott Pilgrim vs. the World Ruined a Whole Generation of Women\' that pokes at the scene girls of that era. And while I may have some distain for this hyperbolic analysis, the comics and movie certainly aren\'t without their own flaws. While Scott might\'ve completed his hero\'s journey, having him win Ramona at the end didn\'t feel like the right ending to what was already very toxic relationship. Something was missing from this arc. When an animated series was announced, produced by Edgar Wright and Bryan Lee O\'Malley, animation by famous Japanese studio Science SARU... AND all the original cast back to voice their respected roles, there was much anticipated buzz about Scott Pilgrim being back in a public eye. But what would that look like? Scott Pilgrim Taking Off left me confused at first, pleasantly surprised later, and falling in love with every single one of these characters again. Between the meta-humor and callbacks, much of this series charm comes from that Episode 1 twist. I\'m glad that I wasn\'t spoiled and, while far from perfect, what we got was wonderful reunion that left me wanting more from this project. Without spoiling too much... Scott needed to be gone for a few episodes to address the flaws that I mentioned earlier. Giving Ramona her time to confront her ex’s allowed us to develop both them and her. Showing us that Bryan really cares about these characters. That they still live inside his head. He could’ve easily done a 1:1 adaptation, but the same hyperbolic criticisms of Ramona and Scott’s relationship would still exist. Just Garden State 2.0 Animated. We often forget that it was nothing short of a miracle that the movie by Edgar Wright even exists. If you prefer the movie over the animated series, more power to you. Just keep this one thing in mind... This series is way more than just about Scott Pilgrim. It\'s about a nerdy, neurodivergent kid from Canada who learned to have respect for himself. Who found love, got married, and later divorced. His story, however, isn\'t the the first and last of it\'s kind. Whoever the next Scott is... I hope to see you in Season 2. Even if it means waiting for a thousand years. ;-)'), ('4', 'The show is not really about Scott, he actually had a minor role in the show. They should have subtitled with Romona flowers in the title to set expectations better. Other than that the show is just meh which is sad since I loved the comics, movies and a lot of the performers in this.'), ('10', 'i can relate to scott pilgrim because i often find myself dating high schoolers'), ('7', 'Scott Pilgrim Takes Off puts an interesting new spin on the popular comic book story, but as with the movie I never found it more than mildly entertaining despite being the sort of outlandish, video game inspired type of thing I always thought I’d love.'), ('10', 'Mindblowingly amazing overall. Characters are really wellwritten, voice actors delivered superb voice acting. The soundtrack is honestly extremely good. The artstyle is one of the best I\'ve seen, one of the main reason why I even watched it in the first place. Not a long-time fan of Scott Pilgrim, this is the very first Scott Pilgrim content I\'ve consumed so far (I might delve into the comics and the liva action movie) so I cannot speak on behalf of the "vetarans".'), ('6', "Carried by rock-solid animation from Science Saru and some incredible scores provided by Anamanaguchi and Trapanese, the show is very unfortunately bogged down by questionable pacing, shoddy editing, amateurish sound design, bad voice work (in the English version, the Japanese and Spanish versions are SPECTACULAR but most people won't watch the show this way like I did). The story tries to go in an interesting direction, but combine that with the aforementioned shoddy pacing, weird character writing that teeters on parody for many characters (looking at you Gideon), and an entirely undeserved and head-scratching climax, Scott Pilgrim Takes Off is something that while I didn't hate, I don't see myself returning to anytime soon, glad that it is finding a home in the hearts of many though even if not me."), ('8', 'It turned out to be a very pleasant surprise, which immediately went to the 2nd viewing. A wonderful addition and expansion to the existing Pilgrim titles and especially for the film from 2010. A stunningly bright piece from which fun and energy are in full swing. The only thing that seemed sagging to me – was that there were few catchy musical moments in scenes and narrative.'), ('5', 'Scott Pilgrim Takes Off is in the end a tote of drugs and insane with an original and referent animation. If the series foreshadowed an interesting second reading, in my opinion it seems to be irrelevant.'), ('8', 'Good, but with wrong title. Ramona is main protagonist. Please, change name for Ramona Flower Takes Off.'), ('5', "Confused on how the creator of the comic and of the movie managed to completely misunderstand their own characters and motivations from the very start. The show was an entertaining elseworlds type story, but overall failed in the concept and execution. Wouldn't recommend for the fans of the comic or movie."), ('2', "Did no one tell these people that geek chic hasn't been in for years? Lovable losers are just weirdo dorks again. Blecch."), ('3', 'When the show doesn’t lean on the movie like a crutch (they one for one remake a lot of scenes in the beginning), it fails miserably. The movie is way more fun, just rewatch that since Scott’s barely in this show due to an ol’ switcherooni.'), ('9', 'This show is amazing! This may not be the story you remember, but it is all the better for it.'), ('2', "Nothing new to offer, same old boring movie in boring anime format. In recent years, the only thing Netflix has done is to cancel most of the works with lesbian characters, even if they are popular. What Netflix does is like giving us a big, fancy-looking gift, but when we open the gift it's empty and empty, Netflix clearly hurts and disappoints us. So, I hope that Netflix Lesbian Phobia will not make another work that has a lesbian character. We do not want your empty and annoying support and hope"), ('8', 'Such a surprise that they followed the new story route. A risk worth taking. Apart from that, this is an enjoyable and engaging series.')}
critic_reviews: {(9.0, 'A breathtaking reimagining of Bryan Lee O’Malley’s graphic novels. Even with the core cast of Scott Pilgrim vs. the World along for the ride, it’s no mere exercise in nostalgia, but a fresh coat of paint on a versatile coming-of-age story, whose vibrant animation and expanded scope bring new dimensions to the garage rockers, video-store clerks, ninja-couriers, and evil exes who inhabit “Toronto, Canada – Not Too Long Ago.”'), (10.0, 'This show has the highly-coveted yet rarely-executed reboot potential to indoctrinate new fans to its universe, without sacrificing the off-kilter humor and heart that endeared the story to its original fanbase. It’s not an easy task by any means, but “Scott Pilgrim Takes Off” shows that it’s possible — and sets a new bar for anyone chasing the joy of the original with a second round.'), (8.0, 'The end of the first episode of Scott Pilgrim Takes Off is bound to turn off some viewers, but just take a deep breath and proceed. By the halfway point, your anger and confusion will fully dissipate as the story plays on and divulges new findings about the beloved characters. If you venture into this series with an open mind, you’ll love it. The show has all the charm, humor, and action of its source material!'), (5.0, '“Scott Pilgrim Takes Off,” directed by Abel Góngora, is more dutiful in its depiction of toxic relationship behaviors and more generous in redeeming its characters — even its antagonists — through their own arcs of personal growth. Too bad those are also the blandest story lines. There are some intriguing new reveals and romantic pairings, along with jamming music from Scott’s band, Sex Bob-Omb (original songs by Anamanaguchi), but the bulk of the eight-episode series feels like a filler arc or, to use an anime term, OVAs (original video animations).'), (9.1, 'Each episode has a distinct energy, and the theme song sequence is one of those you won’t want to skip. Yes, bread still makes you fat, but on the plus side, Scott Pilgrim will still exhilarate you with all the possibilities of pop culture.'), (8.0, 'Insane fights, sparkling animation and a fresh look at an old story — Scott Pilgrim was born to be an anime hero. What a level-up.'), (8.0, 'It isn’t mind-blowing. But it’s fun. So maybe Scott Pilgrim Takes Off isn’t what you expect it to be and maybe that’s both positive and negative and maybe this will never be my favorite version of this world, but there’s much to enjoy in these eight fast-moving episodes.'), (9.5, 'For the person who already loves the property, the anime will deepen that love; for the uninitiated, or those overwhelmed by the movie’s high-speed pacing, it’s a great entry point—an incredibly entertaining, touching action-comedy.'), (10.0, 'This is an adaptation that will stay with us for a while to come and, much like the film, it will definitely be one we rewatch time and time again.'), (5.8, 'While the ending is a major flaw, the series as a whole is still worth your time, mostly due to its wonderful art and performances.'), (6.3, 'So while Scott Pilgrim Takes Off does offer a surprisingly fresh and funny take on its source material, the pieces don’t fit together as neatly as they should.'), (8.3, 'Scott Pilgrim Takes Off takes the long road to get to some of its most affecting moments, and it’s not always a smooth one. But it’s full of laughs, brightly sketched gags, and great character work to make things go down easier. And that payoff, disarmingly romantic and emotionally intelligent, still hits like a truck.'), (8.0, 'Most importantly, it retains the underlying tone and messaging of what came before as it successfully reenvisions this story with Ramona at center stage. In the end, it manages to do something tricky, transposing a more than decade-old tune while barely missing a beat.'), (8.0, 'It’s very good. .... I’m fairly certain the anime works as a standalone piece that introduces Scott Pilgrim to a new generation of audiences, but its grand design can only truly be realized by audiences who have lived with the original story — along with the many discussions sprung from it — for the past decade.'), (9.1, 'Scott Pilgrim Takes Off has cajones, and thank god for it. The show could have been serviceable nostalgia bait, but instead, it delivers a deeply satisfying eight-episode arc, in turn setting a new standard for what legacy sequels can accomplish.'), (10.0, '“Scott Pilgrim Takes Off” is a phenomenal stand-alone addition to the franchise as excellent as the many incarnations before it. Amid remakes and reboots, this rare level-up cleverly reexamines its entire story with a profound twist without sacrificing any pieces of its identity.'), (8.0, '“Scott Pilgrim Takes Off” is simple and fun, but it’s not exactly meant for kids. .... Rather, the show is meant for former kids revisiting an old favorite through more grown-up eyes.'), (9.0, '"Scott Pilgrim Takes Off" is not just a great anime, but one that shows the promise of streaming services in delivering global productions that put together different aesthetics and talents. It is also a fantastic adaptation that proves you can do more than just remake the same thing in a different medium.'), (8.3, 'For a series that has been adapted so many times, it’s refreshing to see a new take on the material. Despite some issues regarding the recycled plot elements, “Scott Pilgrim Takes Off” has assembled a dream team of collaborators with Science Saru, Anamanaguchi, and the original voice cast of the live-action movie to bring this Japanese Anime to life.'), (8.0, 'Some of the sound effects may be lifted from retro video games but the emotions are operatic, evoking that time of life when falling in love is at its most precarious and intense. It’s quite the rush.')}

title: Class of '09
user_reviews: {('10', "The FX series Class Of '09 smartly layers the past, present, and future in telling this story. Introducing viewers to only two-time frames in the first five minutes made everything that happened in these first two episodes easier to absorb. Kate Mara's performance as Poet is so good that you are (easily) pulled into the third time frame (Present 2023) without it feeling disruptive. You could argue that this story could have been just as good without the time jump. But it feels more attractive told this way and complements the dystopian part of the story set in 2034. The showrunners, writers, and actors did a great job showing the good in 2009 and the ugly in 2034 offering only a glimpse of the bad that's about to happen in 2023 with a great cliffhanger at the end of episode two. This direction made it thrilling and fun to watch. Structuring a series like this is difficult and often loses focus with all the back and forth, but this new limited series from FX may be the exception. I look forward to seeing how this story plays out. Keep It Interesting and Stay Channel Surfing Damian At TalkTeaV")}
critic_reviews: {(7.0, 'Few shows have such a unique combination of grounded action and performances with an Orwellian social conscience and special effects splashed flash forwards. If Class of ’09 balances those elements better going forward, it could be as well-rounded, lithe and lethal as the best trained FBI boot camp recruits it is depicting.'), (6.5, "Class of '09 clearly still has much to reveal as it hints at mysteries to come. And maybe those revelations will prove involving enough to alleviate some of the problems with the often poky pacing of these early outings. It's a smart and timely series. But by its halfway point, it's yet to feel like a vital one."), (6.7, 'No matter how many times this limited series gets tied up in the past when its connections to the future are where it is strongest, Henry’s performance makes it worth seeing where it will go.'), (3.0, 'Class Of ’09 is too busy jumping between timelines to tell a cohesive story that has any kind of momentum.'), (7.0, "Just when you think you've seen every variation on an FBI drama, this mix of old school and new has a way of keeping you engaged and alert. [23 May - 11 Jun 2023, p.6]"), (5.0, 'There are worthy performances in the mix, most notably from leads Brian Tyree Henry and Kate Mara, but the actors are working with scattered material that might have benefited from focus and some ruthless paring, particularly when it comes to the awkward expositional dialogue.'), (6.0, 'The personal lives of the characters can grow emotionally moribund. But the action sequences, and the confrontations between Mr. Henry\'s Tayo and the homegrown terrorists he\'s trying to stop, are grippingly violent and intelligently so. Whether "Class of \'09" is operating at peak efficiency depends on who is on screen.'), (4.2, 'lease. Stop it with the multiple timelines. Of late, TV has a tendency to overindulge the structural device, but “Class of ’09” has enough on its plate already to bother with silly gimmicks. Or it should.'), (7.0, 'Sometimes, it feels like the timelines aren’t equal in terms of storytelling or viewer interest, but the writers and editors are smart to let long scenes play out within them before zipping to the next. I hope the show doesn’t get more manic with the time jumps because it’s right on the verge of doing that a bit too much already.'), (7.2, 'Kate Mara, Brian Tyree Henry, Sepideh Moafi: Take a bow. Those three, with an extra emphatic nod to Henry (the brilliant “Paper Boi” from Atlanta) are the saving graces of Class of ’09, an otherwise serviceable but occasionally disoriented FBI thriller from FX (streaming on Hulu).'), (7.5, 'This is a decidedly uneven effort; at times, the action has to come to a screeching halt for expository dialogue, as if the series is acknowledging it has some clarity problems. Still, thanks in large part to that outstanding cast and the cinematic production values, “Class of ’09” could graduate into something memorable.'), (4.2, 'Ultimately, Class Of ’09 crumbles under its weighty issues. Narratives about the FBI or AI aren’t new, but this one doesn’t reinvent the wheel or offer a unique testament.'), (6.0, 'It’s not hard to see what he’s aiming for, even if the results are mixed. The series seems at its most vibrant while following the rookies through Quantico.'), (5.0, 'By erring on the side of intellectual exercise, “Class of ‘09” deprives itself of the chance to give a fresher take on this evergreen dilemma. It’s a show more engaging to think about than it ultimately is to watch.'), (8.0, 'Inventively conceived and deftly executed, it’s a crime saga that comes across a modernized, multi-layered spin on Philip K. Dick’s (and Steven Spielberg’s) Minority Report.'), (6.0, 'Class of ‘09 has ambition but, like many a starry-eyed freshman, spreads itself too thin.'), (10.0, 'It provides the rare feeling that it is exploring every possibility inside its own narrative and is able to excel in everything it tries to do. Whether there are more seasons to pore over or just the one, the ride has already been highly rewarding.'), (5.0, 'Feels like one of those instances in which the trickiness of the split storylines becomes a cover for the sense that, through the four episodes sent to critics, none of the three timelines would be close to interesting enough to sustain interest. The series’ directors, starting with Joe Robert Cole and Sunu Gonera, establish momentum, but struggle to make the individual pieces feel distinctive.'), (7.2, 'Hulu’s FX-produced “Class of ’09” starts slowly but then ratchets up intrigue as the thriller tracks FBI Academy classmates in three time periods. It’s a limited series worth watching.'), (6.0, 'Cerebral, ambitious, but frustratingly paced tale of human fallibility and technological overreach.')}
